name: Kepler-158
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-158 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-158 is a star with 0.5199999999999999 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.62 times its radius. It is located 1037.37 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-158 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-158 b

Kepler-158 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.11 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 16.71 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-158.

The mass of Kepler-158 b is 5.83 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-158 b is 2.12 that of Earth. At 5.83 Earth masses, Kepler-158 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-158 c

Kepler-158 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.16 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 28.55 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-158.

The mass of Kepler-158 c is 4.52 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-158 c is 1.9 that of Earth. At 4.52 Earth masses, Kepler-158 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-158, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
